Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Trans people, just like everyone else, want to be able to travel, start new jobs, open bank accounts, enroll in school, vote — all of those things require some form of ID.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Trans people, just like everyone else, want to be able to travel, start new jobs, open bank accounts, enroll in school, vote — all of those things require some form of ID.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Gender nonconforming people are already under such public scrutiny nationwide.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Gender nonconforming people are already under such public scrutiny nationwide.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: An analysis released in August of respondents to the 2022 U.S. Transgender Survey, widely seen as the most comprehensive study of binary and nonbinary transgender Americans, found that voting-eligible trans people had cast ballots in the last presidential election at a higher rate than the U.S. population.
Document Sources.Source Justification: An analysis released in August of respondents to the 2022 U.S. Transgender Survey, widely seen as the most comprehensive study of binary and nonbinary transgender Americans, found that voting-eligible trans people had cast ballots in the last presidential election at a higher rate than the U.S. population.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: Nearly 21 million voting-eligible U.S. citizens do not have a current driver’s license, according to the Center for Democracy and Civic Engagement at the University of Maryland, whose research was partially supported by VoteRiders.
Document Sources.Name of Source: Center for Democracy and Civic Engagement at the University of Maryland
Document Sources.Source Justification: Nearly 21 million voting-eligible U.S. citizens do not have a current driver’s license, according to the Center for Democracy and Civic Engagement at the University of Maryland, whose research was partially supported by VoteRiders.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: The Williams Institute at the University of California, Los Angeles School of Law, estimated ahead of the 2022 midterm election that more than 200,000 voting-eligible transgender Americans may find it difficult to vote at the time because of voter ID laws.
Document Sources.Name of Source: The Williams Institute at the University of California, Los Angeles School of Law
Document Sources.Source Justification: The Williams Institute at the University of California, Los Angeles School of Law, estimated ahead of the 2022 midterm election that more than 200,000 voting-eligible transgender Americans may find it difficult to vote at the time because of voter ID laws.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “There is a chilling effect,” said Lauren Kunis, CEO and executive director of VoteRiders, which helps voters obtain identification.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: CEO and executive director of VoteRiders
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Lauren Kunis, CEO and executive director of VoteRiders, which helps voters obtain identification.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “A lot is falling on poll workers to correctly enforce the law,” Kunis added.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: CEO and executive director of VoteRiders
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Lauren Kunis, CEO and executive director of VoteRiders, which helps voters obtain identification.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Trans votes count,” said Ankit Rastogi, director of research for the National Center for Transgender Equality, which conducted the survey and will soon be known as Advocates for Trans Equality Education Fund.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Director of research for the National Center for Transgender Equality
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Ankit Rastogi, director of research for the National Center for Transgender Equality, which conducted the survey and will soon be known as Advocates for Trans Equality Education Fund.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Trans people, just like everyone else, want to be able to travel, start new jobs, open bank accounts, enroll in school, vote — all of those things require some form of ID. And so when a state goes out of its way to enforce its message about its belief about sex and gender on a license, and transgender people then have to publicize that when they show other people, it creates a dangerous environment,” he said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Attorney for the ACLU of Tennessee
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Lucas Cameron-Vaughn, an attorney for the ACLU of Tennessee.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “It’s a tactic that’s designed to splinter support for trans rights and suggest sort of who is harmed by protecting trans people — to frame that as cisgender women being the people harmed by protections for trans people,” said Rose Saxe, who is deputy project director for the ACLU’s LGBT & HIV Project.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Deputy project director for the ACLU’s LGBT & HIV Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Rose Saxe, who is deputy project director for the ACLU’s LGBT & HIV Project.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “We saw it as a move to inflict maximum chaos and misunderstanding,” Diaz said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Quinn Diaz, a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “With these laws in Florida, you’re forced to choose between living authentically and just not really participating in public life,” Diaz said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Quinn Diaz, a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I can imagine that a lot of trans folks in Florida who might not have access ... to an accurate and affirming ID might not want to engage in that process at all, especially in such a heightened political environment,” Diaz said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Quinn Diaz, a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Gender nonconforming people are already under such public scrutiny nationwide,” Diaz said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Quinn Diaz, a public policy associate at advocacy group Equality Florida.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “They won’t stop me, but I can see how it would stop others,” she said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Hazel Krebs, a 42-year-old transgender woman living in Kansas, one of the states with a new anti-trans law.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “It is almost certainly stopping some people from showing up at the polls,” she said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Hazel Krebs, a 42-year-old transgender woman living in Kansas, one of the states with a new anti-trans law.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Something that’s very frustrating for us at VoteRiders is you will never be able to capture the number of people who do not feel safe voting, and who therefore stay home. And you also won’t be able to capture the people who are trans and show up to try and vote and are turned away.” Kunis said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: CEO and executive director of VoteRiders
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Lauren Kunis, CEO and executive director of VoteRiders, which helps voters obtain identification.
